thread.title: User Stories for HW 2 and Task 1
thread.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>From reading all the Ed Discussion posts I have deciphered that we need to decide which user stories apply to CRUD functionality. As far as I am concerned the only two items in the user story that applies strictly to CRUD are:</paragraph><list style="bullet"><list-item><paragraph>As a student, I can see a list of questions others have asked that might be related to a question I am about to ask, so I do not waste my time waiting for answers already there, and others don’t waste their time reading and answering my question</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>As a student, I can see a list of all unresolved questions and a list of the current potential answers for each so I can evaluate the potential answers and, if appropriate, propose a new potential answer without duplicating the work of others.</paragraph></list-item></list><paragraph>And then I am implicitly adding a user story (which wasn't included in the document), that the user can modify and delete their questions/answers. This should cover all the bases of CRUD.</paragraph><paragraph>So I just have three total user stories (for task 1). Two from the document and one that I inferred. Would this be a safe and correct approach? </paragraph><paragraph/></document>
thread.document:
From reading all the Ed Discussion posts I have deciphered that we need to decide which user stories apply to CRUD functionality. As far as I am concerned the only two items in the user story that applies strictly to CRUD are:

As a student, I can see a list of questions others have asked that might be related to a question I am about to ask, so I do not waste my time waiting for answers already there, and others don’t waste their time reading and answering my question

As a student, I can see a list of all unresolved questions and a list of the current potential answers for each so I can evaluate the potential answers and, if appropriate, propose a new potential answer without duplicating the work of others.

And then I am implicitly adding a user story (which wasn't included in the document), that the user can modify and delete their questions/answers. This should cover all the bases of CRUD.

So I just have three total user stories (for task 1). Two from the document and one that I inferred. Would this be a safe and correct approach?

thread.title: UML Diagram Clarification
thread.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>For the UML design (not sequence portion), must we make a class box with class name at the top, attributes listed with data type, and finally class methods with return types. This has been standard for UML diagrams. However no where in my investigation does this assignment specify what is expected for our UML diagrams.</paragraph><paragraph>Based on the assignment description I looked here: " Be sure to produce four UML Class Diagrams and at least one Sequence Diagram using the <bold>provided samples</bold> in the "Architecture and Design Documents" portion of the "Individual Homeworks and Team Projects" Module"</paragraph><paragraph>However, none of the provided examples are UML diagrams, only state machine, sequence diagrams, and High-Level Startup Flow diagrams.</paragraph><paragraph>As far as the sequence diagram is concerned, expectations are fully specified (examples are given).</paragraph><paragraph>I appreciate any clarification thank you.</paragraph></document>
thread.document:
For the UML design (not sequence portion), must we make a class box with class name at the top, attributes listed with data type, and finally class methods with return types. This has been standard for UML diagrams. However no where in my investigation does this assignment specify what is expected for our UML diagrams.

Based on the assignment description I looked here: " Be sure to produce four UML Class Diagrams and at least one Sequence Diagram using the provided samples in the "Architecture and Design Documents" portion of the "Individual Homeworks and Team Projects" Module"

However, none of the provided examples are UML diagrams, only state machine, sequence diagrams, and High-Level Startup Flow diagrams.

As far as the sequence diagram is concerned, expectations are fully specified (examples are given).

I appreciate any clarification thank you.

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>There are examples in the textbook that can help you.  If you have questions about one of the examples, please visit one of the numerous office hours available.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
answers.document: There are examples in the textbook that can help you.  If you have questions about one of the examples, please visit one of the numerous office hours available.

thread.title: About the implement for HW2 Questions and Answers
thread.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Do we need to store all the questions and answers into SQL now or we just need to implement the Question, Answer, Questions, Answers class and ignore the storing for now? </paragraph><paragraph/></document>
thread.document: Do we need to store all the questions and answers into SQL now or we just need to implement the Question, Answer, Questions, Answers class and ignore the storing for now?

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>What does the deliverables portion for this assignment ask you to do?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
answers.document: What does the deliverables portion for this assignment ask you to do?

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I'm storing mine in the database and testing it there as well. This is a requirement because CRUD operations (from my understanding) have to do with creating, reading, updating, and deleting. So I THINK those are in relation to how they operate in the database. If not then whatever it's extra work and it teaches me stuff anyways. Plus I have the CRUD operations completed with functionality so it can't be marked down anyways.</paragraph></document>
answers.document: I'm storing mine in the database and testing it there as well. This is a requirement because CRUD operations (from my understanding) have to do with creating, reading, updating, and deleting. So I THINK those are in relation to how they operate in the database. If not then whatever it's extra work and it teaches me stuff anyways. Plus I have the CRUD operations completed with functionality so it can't be marked down anyways.

thread.title: Testing
thread.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>For the testing, does it need to be automated, or can i just manually input the test case and show the subsequent ui error message or success message,</paragraph></document>
thread.document: For the testing, does it need to be automated, or can i just manually input the test case and show the subsequent ui error message or success message,

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Manual testing is time-consuming and often error-prone.  You will be required to do automated testing using JUnit after the midterm, so why not practice now?</paragraph></document>
answers.document: Manual testing is time-consuming and often error-prone.  You will be required to do automated testing using JUnit after the midterm, so why not practice now?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Is the "console app" one and the same thing as the "automated tests"?  Say we write JUnit tests for each class (Question, Answers, QuestionList, AnswerList).  Do we still need a "console app" at that point?  </paragraph></document>
comments.document: Is the "console app" one and the same thing as the "automated tests"?  Say we write JUnit tests for each class (Question, Answers, QuestionList, AnswerList).  Do we still need a "console app" at that point?

thread.title: HW2 GitHub Repo
thread.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Should we make our GitHub repo for HW2 public or can we just add our group's grader to it?</paragraph></document>
thread.document: Should we make our GitHub repo for HW2 public or can we just add our group's grader to it?

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Private, always private for this class. And about adding your group's grader, that's a great question, we will get back to you.</paragraph></document>
answers.document: Private, always private for this class. And about adding your group's grader, that's a great question, we will get back to you.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Yes, you are correct. Your assigned group grader is also grading your individual homework so you may add them. Thanks.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Yes, you are correct. Your assigned group grader is also grading your individual homework so you may add them. Thanks.

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>If your GitHub is public, someone copies your code, uses it, and gets caught, <bold>you</bold> will be liable for an academic integrity violation, along with the person who did the copying. </paragraph><paragraph/></document>
answers.document: If your GitHub is public, someone copies your code, uses it, and gets caught, you will be liable for an academic integrity violation, along with the person who did the copying.

thread.title: For HW2
thread.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hello there,</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>For HW2 I used the same as foundation login/singup page with features added.</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>And then users can login in a discussion form look covers  exactly  90%  of what Ed Discussion does, is this acceptable to do extra features for my submission?</paragraph><paragraph>like it will show the user who posted user can/edit post, reply with a comment, like etc..</paragraph><paragraph>I am going to do all what is needed from me in the Template and added these extra features is this fine,<break/><break/>or that will affect me not getting full grade?</paragraph></document>
thread.document:
Hello there,



For HW2 I used the same as foundation login/singup page with features added.



And then users can login in a discussion form look covers  exactly  90%  of what Ed Discussion does, is this acceptable to do extra features for my submission?

like it will show the user who posted user can/edit post, reply with a comment, like etc..

I am going to do all what is needed from me in the Template and added these extra features is this fine,

or that will affect me not getting full grade?

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Based on common responses in Ed discussion about extra features, simply put, as long as deliverables have been met, you can add extra features. (they <bold>won't</bold> contribute to the assignment grade, ie extra credit)</paragraph></document>
answers.document: Based on common responses in Ed discussion about extra features, simply put, as long as deliverables have been met, you can add extra features. (they won't contribute to the assignment grade, ie extra credit)

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Yes, but make sure you highlight the basic requirements first in your submission so as to make it easier for the graders to grade</paragraph></document>
answers.document: Yes, but make sure you highlight the basic requirements first in your submission so as to make it easier for the graders to grade

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Like is it okay to add the main requirements in the UML and the extra features there in the UML as well?</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Like is it okay to add the main requirements in the UML and the extra features there in the UML as well?

answers.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>There is no need to sign in to HW2.  There are no roles.  You are just creating and testing classes you will need to use in TP2.</paragraph><paragraph>Please read the deliverables for each assignment carefully.  Where does it suggest that you need to log in?</paragraph></document>
answers.document:
There is no need to sign in to HW2.  There are no roles.  You are just creating and testing classes you will need to use in TP2.

Please read the deliverables for each assignment carefully.  Where does it suggest that you need to log in?

comments.content: <document version="1.0"><paragraph>That’s what I am saying, i just included the login/signup part so it can show who posted this specific post, to make it more organized is this fine? I did not include the login part in the template it’s just in the code. </paragraph></document>
comments.document: That’s what I am saying, i just included the login/signup part so it can show who posted this specific post, to make it more organized is this fine? I did not include the login part in the template it’s just in the code.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Be sure to make it very clear where the CRFUD + Input Validation is in the README.  You are submitting much more code than you need to.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: Be sure to make it very clear where the CRFUD + Input Validation is in the README.  You are submitting much more code than you need to.
